prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HD 97048 B6 12CO, 13CO and C18O (J=2-1) +cont.
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect the 0.43" gap in the disk around HD 97048 and look for 12CO, 13 CO and C18O J=2-1 emission to trace the disk-gap gas contents and the flaring angle of the outer disk

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: For the purpose of resolving line emission in the gap finer spectral resolution is better. in order to observe both the 13CO and C18O, the finest resolution we can request is 0.33 km/s / channel. We can rebin in wider bins to increase the SN if required.

Band 6 represents the best compromise between the decreasing disk flux and weather constraints, and increasing ALMA sensitivity with wavelength and spatial resolution. Because of beam elongation effect we request 0.22" resolution, which will allow us to resolve the disk gaps with 2 beams. The CO 1-0 emission (downloaded from the archive, program 2012.1.00031.S) extents to a maximum of 6 arcseconds. The chosen angular resolution of 0.22 arcseconds is a compromise between angular resolution (still 2 beams in the gap) and sensitivity/beam for the line observations.

The CO 3-2 line has been detected by Hales et al. 2015 to be 7.8 Jy km/s, whereas to estimate the (1-0) strength we downloaded the now public ALMA data on HD 97048 (cycle 0 PI S. Schnee, band 3 with a beamsize of 2.8"x1.8") to be ~6.5 Jy km/s. We estimate the 12CO J=2-1 line strength to be ~7 Jy km/s.
Science goal 2 (calculate the gap depth) drives our observation time. To estimate the required line sensitivity we use the cycle 0 ALMA observations of CO gas inside the gap in the disk around HD 142527 [20], who follow the same analytical approach that we propose. The 12CO J=2-1 line strength of HD 142527 is intermediate between the extrapolated ${^12}$CO J=2-1 line strength of HD 97048 and HD 34282. With a 1 $\sigma$ RMS of 13 mJy, [20] reach a 5 $\sigma$ / beam detection of the $^{13}$CO emission in the brightest channel inside the gap. Given that our beam (for a similar shape) is $\approx$ 8.5 times smaller, that we aim for a 3 $\sigma$ detection of the $^{13}$CO emission and that our spectral channels are a factor of 0.33/0.20 wider, we request a line sensitivity of 4.2 mJy / beam.
based on the comparison to CO 2-1 ALMA observations of gas in the gap in the disk around HD 142527, a star similar to HD 97048, we estimate that a line sensitivity of 4.2 mJy/channel gets us a SNR of 2-3 in the brightest 13CO channels *inside* the gap
We estimate the peak continuum flux density per beam based on processing our SED fit in CASA using the simobserve and simanalyze tasks (band 6, 0.22" resolution) to be 11 mJy, leading to a SNR of 340 in the continuum using 2 bands (4.1 GHz effective bandwidth).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HD 34282 B6 12CO, 13CO and C18O (J=2-1) +cont.
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect the 0.44" gap in the disk around HD 34282 and look for 12CO, 13 CO and C18O J=2-1 emission to trace the disk-gap gas contents and the flaring angle of the outer disk

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: For the purpose of resolving line emission in the gap finer spectral resolution is better. in order to observe both the 13CO and C18O, the finest resolution we can request is 0.33 km/s / channel. We can afterwards rebin in wider bins to increase the SN if required.

Band 6 represents the best compromise between the decreasing disk flux and weather constraints, and increasing ALMA sensitivity with wavelength and spatial resolution. Because of beam elongation effect we request 0.22" resolution, which will allow us to resolve the disk gaps with 2 beams.
Pietu et al. (2003) resolve the disk with a radius of 2", leading to an estimate for the largest angular schale of 4". The chosen angular resolution of 0.22 arcseconds is a compromise between angular resolution (2 beams in the gap) and sensitivity/beam for the line observations.

Science goal 2 (calculate the gap depth) drives our observation time. To estimate the required line sensitivity we use the cycle 0 ALMA observations of CO gas inside the gap in the disk around HD 142527 [20], who follow the same analytical approach that we propose.
The CO 3-2 line of HD 34282 has been detected by Greaves et al. 2000 to be ~27 Jy km/s and estimate the CO 2-1 line flux to be of the same order of magnitude (following HD 97048).
The ${^12}$CO J=2-1 line strength of HD 142527 is with 17 Jy km/s intermediate between the extrapolated ${^12}$CO J=2-1 line strength of HD 97048 and HD 34282. With a 1 $\sigma$ RMS of 13 mJy, [20] reach a >5 $\sigma$ / beam detection of the $^{13}$CO emission in the brightest channel inside the gap. Given that our beam (for a similar shape) is $\approx$ 8.5 times smaller, that we aim for a 3 $\sigma$ detection of the $^{13}$CO emission and that our spectral channels are a factor of 0.33/0.20 wider, we request a sensitivity of 4.2 mJy / beam / channel.
based on this comparison to CO 2-1 ALMA observations of gas in the gap in the disk around HD 142527, a star similar to HD 34282, we estimate that a line sensitivity of 4.2 mJy/channel gets us a SNR of 4-5 in the brightest 13CO channels *inside* the gap
We estimate the peak continuum flux density per beam based on processing our SED fit in CASA using the simobserve and simanalyze tasks (band 6, 0.22" resolution) to be 2.7 mJy, leading to a SNR of 84 in the continuum using 2 bands (4.1 GHz effective bandwidth).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HD 100453 B6 12CO, 13CO and C18O (J=2-1) +cont.
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect the 0.3" gap in the disk around HD 34282 and look for 12 and 13 CO J=2-1 emission to trace the disk-gap gas contents and the flaring angle of the outer disk

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: For the purpose of resolving line emission in the gap, finer spectral resolution is better. in order to observe both the 13CO and C18O, the finest resolution we can request is 0.33 km/s / channel. We can rebin in wider bins to increase the SN if required.

Band 6 represents the best compromise between the decreasing disk flux and weather constraints, and increasing ALMA sensitivity with wavelength and spatial resolution. Because of beam elongation effect we request 0.22" resolution, which will allow us to resolve the disk gaps with a bit over 1 beam.
This star is a binary system, with a companion at ~ 1" distance and a circumprimary disk < 0.9" radius. There is no information on a possible circumsecondary disk. Assuming a similar angular extaent for the circumbinary disk as that of the circumprimary, the maximum angular size expected i3 3". The chosen angular resolution of 0.22 arcseconds is a compromise between angular resolution (a bit over 1 beam in the gap) and sensitivity/beam for the line observations.

The CO 3-2 line in this source is not detected with an upper limit of 0.0077 K km/s for a 10km/s spectral window. This translates to a maximum amount of 0.33 Mjup of cold gas (Collins et al. 2009). We will go about 20 times deeper with our proposed RMS of 4.2 mJy/channel/beam assuming a line width of 5 km/s and 0.3 km/s spectral resolution. This translates into ~5 earth masses of cold gas.
We estimate the peak continuum flux density per beam based on processing our SED fit in CASA using the simobserve and simanalyze tasks (band 6, 0.22" resolution) to be 1.4 mJy, leading to a SNR of 44 in the continuum using 2 bands (4.1 GHz effective bandwidth).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Gaps in disks are a signpost of disk dispersion and planet formation, but finding disk gaps is challenging. Spectral Energy Distribution (SED) studies of the dust disks do not provide unequivocal evidence for gaps, especially in disks around higher mass Herbig Ae/Be stars. Recently it has been suggested the Herbig stars classified as flaring are in fact disks with developing or fully cleared gaps. We propose to test this hypothesis by imaging three flaring HAEBE disks for which strong indirect evidence of such gaps exists, but for which no gaps have been resolved using direct imaging. Using the 13CO, 12CO and C18O J=2-1 isotopes, we also measure the gass mass inside the gaps to constrain the gap opening mechanism, and in the outer disk to measure the amount of flaring of the gas disk.
This is a modified resubmission of proposal 2013.1.00658.S. This proposal uses another band (band 6 in stead of 7) with slightly coarser spatial resolution but a 3 times higher line sensitivity. Since resolving the gaps in the continuum is the main science driver of this proposal, any observations made during cycle 2 of this program do not have to be repeated for cycle 3.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
